commentBody:
A tour de force!

Bravo, Brandon.



Sunday POY contender in my book. U?
AHA! fantastic...As usual I solved not really understanding the theme....But then I read the hint over and over a few times... And BINGO!
That is a ridiculously cool concept. Why I love crosswords. Bravo on finding a way to make it work!
Good theme ruined by two Naticks. ARRID/DELLA and WURLITZER/KUDZU. Could have brute forces one of them, but not two. Well, time to watch the ponies
Got the theme faster than the rebuses. Big Star Wars fan here. Lots of fun clues. Loved seeing Lord Vader in a Star Wars related puzzle

Loved it. I was trying to make “May the Force Be With You” fit, in which case I was going to complain that all the U’s should be in rebuses, but once I noticed the date and had the proper revealer I was mollified. LORD VADER was a great bonus. Great fun!

The reply is hidden, so I'm reposting it here: New Yorkers should know... "The largest Wurlitzer organ originally built (in terms of pipes), was the four-manual / 58-rank (set of pipes) instrument at Radio City Music Hall in New York City. The Music Hall instrument is actually a concert instrument, capable of playing a classical as well as non-classical repertoire." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wurlitzer

"I can't eat this spaghetti with a spoon."
"Use the forks, Luke."

(That pun is the Obi-Wan that I know.)

I am so glad i read what the significance of the rebus was. It would have never occurred to me. I knew it had something to do with Star Wars-maybe putting all the pairs of letters was something Yoda said? Very clever.

Impressive puzzle

flyspecking adnauseam


I spat game but the puzzle was having none of it.

I do not know these films. I had MAYTHESTARWARSWITHYOU for the longest time. And LORDPATER. But appreciated the revealer once I looked at the date and it clicked.

Somehow I got my gold star after an hour and ten minutes.

I am struggling to match BEGRUDGING to "Given reluctantly". Shouldn't the clue be "Giving reluctantly"?

I’d done the Saturday puzzle with its front-and-center zoomies just a few minutes before I started on this one, so I still had dogs on my mind (apologies, Señor Gato; we love your zoomies just as much) when I came across the RHODESIAN Ridgeback. Ohh, the memories… We were once the humans who belonged to a very special Rhody/Rottie mix. 

I’ve read that, if you’re a dog person, you will love all the dogs to which you’ll belong in your life. But that there will be that one dog—or three—who will be extra special. You’ll understand her—or them—in a way that runs more deeply than with the rest of your dogs, and she—or they—will see through all the way to the very essence of you. My first dog was that dog. Then, of the three I had when I met my husband, although I loved all of them equally fiercely, my Rhody/Rottie was my second “that dog.” My husband used to say that if she’d been born a person (and if you asked her, she *had* been), she would’ve been me, and had I been a dog, I would have been her. We were two of a kind. 

After she left us, followed within a year by our other two dogs, I thought I couldn’t do the happiness-always-ends-in-such-pain cycle again. But then The Dog found us, and she turned out to be one of those special dogs again. Incidentally, The Dog, the New Mexico desert product that she was, had a horror of KUDZU. But that’s another story. 

And now only Señor Gato is left to execute joyous zoomies before BED CHECK. 

And execute them he does, dogblesshim.
Note also that the letters paired with U, read from top to bottom, are STARWARS. Very clever!
I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle, even though I am not a big Star Wars fan.
I bet Eddie would say he D/Un did this P/Uzz.
Oh my, what a dreadful pun - even by crossword standards! Only had to stare at the completed puzzle for five minutes to get it. ;-)
I wish it could've lasted longer but I enjoyed the levels of "aha" throughout. Fun, clever. Thank you, Brandon! NB: For a moment I thought we were in chemistry land with AU for GOLD or something.
Brandon constructed this whole grid on one day? I'm in awe!
Yoda one who thought this would be easy. Leia’d flat by clue 12, Luke’d hopeless, Han’d over my will to live. Obi-Wan was my only hope.

Please eli5 why there are two letters in one box.  As a new player, that is no fun on at least three levels: due to spacing you are gaslit into thinking your answer is wrong when it is right, there are infinite possibilities for answers esp. with the lame use of compound phrases to the point where knowledge feels nearly useless, I have no idea how to enter these dual-letter hacks/cheats, it just feels so lazy and sloppy in the part of the NYT, and on and on.  Sorry but there is a lot of pain involved in just figuring out what you want from the player, lol.
Very very cute theme!! CU next week.

Still a bit easy (in keeping with this past week's trend) but probably the most challenging of the lot, even if only mildly.

But... I think this is significant.  This is a relatively rare example where, I think, it would be virtually impossible to derive the theme without filling in the "revealer".  I can't even imagine someone being able to put that together after filling in everything from crosses.  Not saying this is good or bad (though if pressed I'd vote bad) but it sure was interesting to me...

___________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Loved it, from the goofiness of KSTEW to the surrealism of blow-up dolls, wurlitzer organs and Vitruvian Man...great cluing, not often-encountered entries -- Statelier, Lettuce Wrap -- and the tie-in words, like Lord Vader, Cloaks, and to end it on "Miss You," seems like a beautifully constructed grid. 

My Woonsocket (I.e., a semi-Natick) occurred in the cross of Heman and Semisonic. I did choose the right letter in the end, but I debated Hexan / Sexisonic, and was leaning that way until a voice much like Alec Guinness's spoke within me, and statelier tones I have never heard: "John Ezra...remember, use the Force young kudzu...but meantime catch me at the West End--I'm in a revival of Ibsen's A Doll's House, K-Stew plays the blow-up doll and I play...what do I play? Piano! It's a musical after all. Au revoir, my little lettuce wrap, miss you!" And with that, the voice was gone...did y'all hear that voice inside your crania?

The etymology of PUCE, the color, is from "puce*," the French for "flea," although, given their size, I doubt I've ever noticed that fleas have any color what so ever. Puce is also the name of town in Essex County, Ontario, northeast of Windsor, on the south shore of Lake St. Clair. My guess is the town received its name from some prevalence of sand-flies thereabouts. The demonym of its residents remains a topic of dispute: are they Pucites? Putians? Puckers? I wonder if our doggie-avatared friend from Chicago will edit his user name to reflect 97A? I was disappointed that 122A didn't work out to SE[XU]ALITY, with an [XU] rebus. But it did give me my '90s earworm: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h1DDndY0FLI. (Album actually came out in 1989.) *wiktionary traces "puce" all the way back to "*plúlis," the word in the speech of the flea-bitten Proto-Indo-Europeans.
I want to comment on this puzzle, but everything that comes to mind sounds peevish, even to me.  So I'll pass.
BLOWUPDOLL took my breath away.
Whoa, that was impressive Brandon Koppy! And so quickly done too. I liked how the re uses worked both ways and I didn’t get the trick until I finally got Vitruvian Man!
My favorite Sunday in a long time! Such a clever theme. Great work!

Whenever I see KUDZU the word, I think of my mom commenting on its overwhelming presence on the backroads in Arkansas. 

May she RIP.

I'm so ANGSTy about the comments section glitches. I was about to copy my comment just in case and poof, all gone. It never used to do that.😭

Anyhow, SIGHING, that aside, I enjoyed the puzzle a lot! Also really enjoyed the nice long nap I took between the Saturday and Sunday puzzles. It's been a puzzling, but thoroughly unproductive, day.

Great theme! Didn't take much to fill in the revealer but it ELICITed much gladness! And, importantly, it explained the little issues I was having throughout the grid. I suspected a rebus but I tend to fill around and be patient until I uncover enough. It was a delight. 

Only wish I'd figured out the part about the rebus squares spelling STARWARS myself. I found out thanks to Avi in NYC mentioning it below. Definitely increased my enjoyment and respect for the puzzle. So glad we didn't have to wait until 2031. 

Note to self: slow down to review the puzzle better once complete, especially when there are fun tricks. 

BLOWUPDOLL! Ha!! I highly recommend the movie "Lars and the Real Girl," if you have watched it. Really good and sweet movie.

AGES filled in way too fast as "Goes from zero to 60." I'm not quite at 60, but where I am feels like it's happened in a snap, so the visual of pressing on the gas for AGES was poignant. 

INNIE! I wonder if my INNIE likes to do crossword puzzles too. Hmm. I'm sure she likes VODKA though... loved the clue for that at 108D.

Cheers and MAYTHEFOURTHBEWITHYOU! 🍸
Re: Semisomoc: I always liked “Every new beginning comes from some other beginning’s end.“

I would give anything to convince a constructor that, since there have been so many Sunday gadget puzzles, maybe it would be a gadget puzzle to do one that's not a gadget puzzle. This one was so especially cutesy, though.

I briefly wondered if "Big name in organs" might be pancreas. 

Don't worry, I didn't wonder too long, but it did amuse me.

Got the trick two seconds after finishing.  Kinda cool anyway.

Can only imagine the rage out there.  That's the Sunday puzzle 4U.
And also with U!
87 across made me chuckle. Really fun puzzle and satisfying AHA moment!!

Living where I do, I know the park that I will NOT be going anywhere near tomorrow, even if I could get a park reservation. For those not in the know, I live very close to Disney World, and Hollywood Studios is where all the Star Wars rides are located. It's going to be packed tomorrow. Anyhow, the puzzle was fun, rebuses were not difficult to discover or fill in, and the revealer, when understood, made it even easier. I did miss that the letters sharing with U spelled out STAR WARS, so thanks to Avi for pointing it out earlier. I'm impressed by the quality and speed of construction in getting this done in time for a Sunday 5/4; definitely prefer not waiting for another six years. Thanks, Brandon! A couple of songs by Thom Shepherd come to mind; the first definitely applies to 13D, and the second has to do with closing times: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IDWQL0EFpjE https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XUQ8NrmGK2s
Next week's gimmick will be twenty words purposefully spelled incorrectly.  They are not going to tell you which ones, or have any logical pattern on how they are misspelled!

Hey, I didn't see a thread for Strands on Saturday's comment board.

Did I miss it or did no one choose to play or post? 

Personally, and without any spoilers, I was immediately turned off as soon as the grid appeared by something in the upper right that I couldn't miss. Oh well, it's only an occasional game for me so I'll just go ahead and skip so I don't have to keep scanning over it. 

Went back to look to see if anyone else commented on it but I don't see any, so I thought I'd try here.

When I saw all those proper names my heart sank, but I started in and one by one, they fell into place with some brilliant crossing.  It was the trusty GINSUKNIFE that cut through the confusion and told me how to solve the puzzle.  

I took my time, relishing each of the U clues, and delighting in the fun of knowing how to use them.  I had one mistake at the end (I checked every possible fill and pounced on NONGMO, until I remembered the clue and why I had written it in), and almost gave up.  COCO finally gave the the congratulations.

Thank you, Brandon Koppy.  This was a honey of a Sunday puzzle.

Well that was fun! I’m still in the ranks of those delighted to figure out that it IS a rebus puzzle, let alone solve it. As always, I sniffed at the unknown culinary clue for a Japanese herb; in northern Michigan, SHISO sounds like the start of a tongue twister. But everything unknown appeared through crosses. 

I think I just learned on Jeopardy that VITRUVIAN MAN is a commissioned drawing, of a fellow named Vitruvius. 

I bet someone here knows if that’s true. Seems an odd pose to me for a commission.

I fell on my sword. 

Between VIT(RU)VIANMAN and COCO ( i guess I need to study Pixar titles, as they appear almost every day, I just couldn't full this one out.

Can anyone tell me where Vitruvia is?

Happy Star Wars Day in advance! (And to the Star Wars haters, sorry guys. It's our time to shine.) I LOVED this puzzle, even without noticing the added bonus of the SU squares spelling out Star Wars, which I learned of in the comments here. I should have suspected there was more to it when I noticed there were two SUs, two AUs, and two RUs, but it didn't occur to me to check. GINSU KNIFE told me right away there were rebuses, and LETTUCE WRAPS confirmed that the rebuses would be letters followed by U, so I didn't need the revealer to solve the puzzle, but it sure was a delightful discovery. I miss going to movies at the Castro Theater in San Francisco and hearing the Mighty WURLITZER played before the show. https://youtu.be/Bqw7Wgk4nQ4?si=-VkLBY6CZFLtk1Uy This puzzle has quite a few entries I didn't know, but its brilliance is that all of them except one filled in easily from crosses. (The only remaining square where I had to run the alphabet at the end was the cross of SDSU and DNA, but I think if I had taken time to mull it over, I could have gotten DNA without knowing the song just because it's logical.) I mean seriously, if you didn't know VITRUVIAN MAN but could get it 100% from crosses, that's good construction in my book. YMMV. And now I have "Closing Time" stuck in my head even though I didn't remember the name of the band, and now that I see it, I'm not sure I ever knew it, but that song was ubiquitous in 1998.
I prefer to do crossword puzzles on my tablet, but it can’t handle rebuses.  I would be happy if I never saw another rebus again.

when i figured out the theme, i caught such a wave of admiration/amusement that it made me giddy. 

gosh i’m so glad i got into crosswords.  how great to have a natural source of dopamine like that.
Just the wurst! (Bunless cookout entrees, that is.)
Companion who might take your breath away - BLOWUPDOLL was completely inspired. Bravo 👏🏾 👏🏾 👏🏾 👏🏾 👏🏾

Oh, that was fun!

Thanks!

Makingdo with the usual Sunday grid?
Too tired for beerpong, yet ready for something chewier than lettucewraps?
Want a departure from statelier solves?

DO I EVER!
It's been ages since I've had to urn it. 

FSTOP the press!
Just spat my vodka out.

Could it be anemia in the crania?
I asp you this -  is it me or U that scoots over eight times?
On a Sunday?

Brandon Koppy! A heman who brings solvers to their knees and moisture to their palms.
He's the Lord Vader that cloaks the gold star.
He's a Vitruvian man who shocks the tildes off lesser Ns!
His ginzu knife got past the kudzu of adnauseam oreos, enos and onos.
His wordplaying Wurlitzer puts odienary pianos to shame!

Sure. I'll barre it all like a friendly blowup doll and admit it - the terra solva is abetter place when you can seeto letters in one square!

Bedcheck. Gotta turn down the hifi. Now where's that sleep mask?
I had entered the Rebus squares as A/B but the puzzle would not solve.   Re entered as just AB and I got completed.  I am confused.   Solving on an iPhone.    Almost lost my streak.    Am I alone?
Great puzzle! And extra credit for the timeliness, nailing it on the 4th is awesome.
99D is misspelled. I’m sure there’s a variant, but the standard spelling is -OR. Had to go through the whole thing to find this “mistake”.

Well, wookiee there! We got us a rebus! RU kidding me??

I enjoyed this immensely. I found it clever and fun, with just the right amount of Chewie. What a great way to start a Sunday.
A delight! Thanks Brandon.
I do not understand why Net is the answer to the clue "Land" in 37A.   What am I not seeing?
This is one of my favorites in a long time! Really enjoyed figuring out how the rebus worked.
“Black Hole Sun” can get stuck in my head any day. Soundgarden was one of the great rock bands of the 90s. The other two I can do without though

First Sunday in a while that’s had areBUs.  I didn’t note that the rebus was consistently in the fourth square.  Nice touch.  That’s two days in a row with very fast (for me) solve times, but lots of fun answers along the way.  I loved the clue third degrees for PHDS.

Great puzzle! I love that the letters next to the U spell STAR WARS. I always take the time in puzzles like this to see if the special letters spell anything, and this time I wasn't disappointed. I'm not even a SW fan, but I appreciate the bonus. Tom Waits "Closing Time": https://youtu.be/ZGWJ5XiwbV0?si=-ym2AmEc11g8sE7H

I love that the rebus squares are the fourth square in each theme answer.

That, on top of the first rebus letters spelling STAR WARS, and having all the theme answers have the letter count to enable them to be symmetrically placed -- is masterful puzzle construction.

Bravo, Brandon!

Real fun Sunday puzzle!  Favorite clues: TILDES, PHDS, HENRI, BLOWUPDOLL (brilliant!).
Hope to see more from you, so "Let's go Brandon!!".

Oh dear, feel like I'm going to rain on the parade - but for me this was the most tedious crossword since I started 6 months ago. Nothing to do with the trick - I saw almost at once that there was a U missing. 
But apart from Ibsen and Abba I knew none of the proper names, brands or sport clues, and there were a quite lot. The brand name of something which begins GINS is pretty hard to guess (you know the brand names of knives?) also KSTEW, and in fact LETTUCE WRAPS was tricky for me. 
Cookouts not that common in our climate. Last week 25C/78F (and that's a heatwave) today 11C/52F.

I don't believe Star Wars Day is celebrated in UK, never seen or heard it mentioned. I saw the Star Wars film in !977 and none since so not possible to remember much! 

So, on to next week.
Agusta…will get you since it’s misspelled. Augusta is correct.

It just occurred to me that Star Wars may be the same kind of defining cultural moment for Gen X that the The Beatles were for Boomers. A little something for everybody here, but this is their puzzle and I can appreciate the fun they must be having with it.

Whew. And Wow! When I glanced at my desktop calendar this morning, MAYTHEFOURTHBEWITHYOU had actually popped into my head. But I was still well into the puzzle for a good long time before I had enough crosses for the reveal to finally dawn on me. I should probably go buy some lottery tickets. 

Anyway... this is just one truly amazing feat of construction. Can't even imagine how much work it must taken to... first - find all those possible answers with a 'U' in the needed position, and then... somehow manage to work them all into a grid pattern. Wow. Just wow. 

And, of course I had a puzzle find today. REALLY unusual one. I'll put that in a reply. 

....

I love the backstory, that Brandon came up with this puzzle idea in January, realized it HAD to be done, realized that it was very late in the game to have it come out the first week of May, then fashioned the grid – designed and filled it! – in ONE DAY, then clued 140 answers in TWO DAYS, then hurried it in.

I repeat, in single day he crafted a puzzle with such hard-to-attain features (symmetrical theme answers whose fourth letters are rebuses, the first letters of which spell STAR WARS) – and the result doesn’t feel forced!  Nor do the clues feel hastily thrown together.  

Furthermore, the answer set includes sixteen NYT debut answers, including lovelies NON-GMO, SENSUALITY, ELICITING, and DO I EVER.  On top of that, there are excellent original clues, such as [Book reviews, of sorts] for TAX AUDITS, and [Baby monitors] for NANNIES.

This is a backstory with notes of talent, skill, and passion.  It is a story with a very happy ending – an impressive and pleasing-to-many puzzle that successfully landed on the day it was born to land on.

So yes, I’m wowed by what led up to your puzzle, Brandon, as well as grateful for the splendid outing it gave me.  Standing O!
I’m not a Star Wars fan (despite being prime Gen X), but because today is my birthday I immediately knew the revealer. I’ll consider it my first gift of the day :)
Excellent aha moment when I understood what was happening with the theme and some nice cluing (especially blowupdoll). Best Sunday for a while in my book

I'm a fan of the original Star Wars movie, but lost interest thereafter.  And while I've been known to perpetrate the occasional pun, MAY THE FOURTH BE WITH YOU is exactly the sort of laboured "not quite working" pun that makes me sympathize with the recently cited John Oliver quote. So big sigh from me, today.
I cottoned on to the theme fairly early, and then the grid in my browser stopped letting me enter rebuses, which made getting the crosses unreasonably hard. The fill then turned out to be a black-and-white mixture of stuff I immediately knew and stuff I couldn't possibly get, with very little in the middle ground.

I crashed and burned with the cluster of unknowables at 73, 74 and 75D, flanked by the American usage at 69D and a US airport code at 68D, and crossed by an unknown movie at 86A. Not that it would have helped salvage that area, but I also couldn't figure out the crosser at 78A, given only the initial "C". So that was when I hit "Reveal".

Thieves wear CLOAKS? Have you ever tried to climb through a window wearing a cloak? (I have---long story.) 
Is this some sort of RPG "invisibility cloak" thing?

Tight, fun theme! Not only made *me* grin, puzzle-snubbing hubby even smiled at that. And the way it pointed out exactly where to find the squished letters! Masterful! Two answers *and* the revealer had me racing to this 3-ish minutes of comedy gold… Enjoy! https://youtu.be/xxX7QCll3oc?si=GTmIEgz5XJlJJdV5 Thank you, Brandon!
THANK U

I nominate this for Puzzle of the Year… perhaps ever! 
Thanks, Brendan!

Just before tackling the puzzle I saw a post on FB with a graphic that said "May the Fourth Be With You." It was the first time I'd ever seen that expression. Got off the computer, took my printed puzzle to the place in the kitchen where I always do the puzzle, and lo and behold, there it was again! Looked at the puzzle's date, and was off to the races.

Now, I know virtually nothing about Star Wars. Never saw the movie. Or maybe I did and was stoned in those days. Really, the only things I know about it, namely the names, I learned from the puzzles. 

But GINSU KNIVES jumped out right away, so it was fairly easy to figure out the rest of the answers, with a few exceptions: LETTUCE WRAPS, for instance. Easy to deduce, but why cookout food? I've only had them in restaurants, where they're usually appetizers.

The trick was straightforward, the sports-related answers annoying, and there were too many of them. Not one of my favorite puzzles. Finished in rather speedy time, but was totally bored. Not my cuppa tea.
Aaand 365 in a row.  This one came quickly, and if it wasn’t for Abettor would have been close to a PB.

Can someone tell me what the "time stamp" link to a posted comment is?

I am guessing it is the link below the link that says "View your comment," but I wanted to make sure.

Thanks

I enjoyed this but just a note that the guide here consistently gives the / as part of the rebus (which I thought added to the “with” part of the solution) but it wouldn’t solve that way for me, I had to go back and simply concatenate the letters, no slashes, and then it “solved.”

Not my favorite, but I didn’t hate it. It seems I am alone in that; everyone in the comments section seems to have loved it.   I figured out the rebus part, though I was in the dark about it being the fourth square so I didn’t understand where the consistency was with the rebuses.  That was what I found a little frustrating.  Just a me thing, I guess.   Perhaps I am just grouchy today and need to eat my breakfast.   Now that I have read the column, I can fully appreciate the elegance of the construction though.

I did figure out the REBUS motif, but placed most of them one square off. It made for confusing adjacent entries, which didn't phase me at first. I had to stare the _almost_ completed puzzle down for quite some time before fixing them. 

Having been in the tech industry for 44 years, May the 4th and Pi day were celebrated adnAUseUM

Fun and challenging! Saw how to enter the rebus boxes but didn’t “get” the rebus til I read the column. 

I don’t think of a Thunderbird as a sports car, by the way. Maybe that’s just me. Actually not sure how I’d classify it.

Strands #427
“Star Wars: A New Hope”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🟡🔵🔵

NO SPOILERS UNTIL AFTER VIEW ALL REPLIES, PLEASE 

Perhaps the title will encourage fans of today's crossword who don't normally play Strands to give it a try.

Just about right for a Sunday. Caught on to the rebuses (rebi?) pretty much right away and since my sons and daughters and I share a love of most things Star Wars (you can keep episodes I - III, thank you) found the theme, and its revealer, delightful. (I wished them all Happy Star Wars Day nearly first thing). They’re in their 30s and 40s now…but in the summer between his sophomore and junior years of high school, my second oldest son set himself the project of watching the original trilogy on VHS over and over, at the rate of an episode a day. He must have watched each movie around 30 times, I’d guess, and can still quote dialogue verbatim roughly 30 years later.

As for the CW itself: wonderful job of constructing…and that, subtracting the Us, the theme answers spell STAR WARS in order: brilliant.
Maybe if they had called themselves ‘Sexasonic’ they would have made it past the one hit wonder status.   And don’t forget the Hexans of the 6th planet in the Shortzwilly system.
Loved, loved, LOVED it! So clever, and a fun Sunday solve! Perfect timing for this one. Thank you, Brandon, for a magnificent puzzle.

Ah, this was great.

I got GINSUKNIFE right away, although I wasn't sure where to put the rebus to make it work. I continued to zip through, on pace for a good time, but I got stalled in the top right. Not familiar with the play in question, so I started with ALBEE, which was way off on the wrong track.

VITRUVIANMAN? saw it a mile away, but as with one or two of the other rebuses, I wasn't quite sure where the rebus should go; didn't pick up on the fourth square element of it until the end.

Great start to a dreary Sunday.
MAJOR fan of rebuses here. Thank you Brandon for a stellar (!) puzzle!

Excellent puzzle for MAY THE FOURTH.  Got the revealer quickly, took longer to figure out it also was a rebus.  I liked there were less pop culture references to look up than in other recent Sunday puzzles.  Today ties my old consecutive streak of 224 days.   Happy Star Wars Day!
Unpleasant.

Very clever and fun puzzle. I love -may the fourth be with "U". Ha!

To Brandon Koppy -

  If you like Semisonic, check out the band in their previous, expanded form, Trip Shakespeare.

Another little easteUregg:  66D -- TBIRD -- goes back to George Lucas' earlier movie, American Graffitti.  He made that movie as a total unknown on a miniscule budget.  It was all filmed outdoors, except the dance, filmed at Tamalpias High.  I think he went to High School there, or close by.  The movie was a big hit, and made Lucas the money to do his real dream -- Star Wars.

Suzanne Summers, in her first 'real' movie role, drove that little white 1956 Thunderbird that had Richard Dreyfus drooling after her.  He was also an unknown.  I think the only known actor in the movie was Ron Howard.  So many others got their start in American Graffitti, including Harrison Ford.

I'm partial to that movie because I own a duplicate 1956 TBIRD that my dad bought knew.  I've had it since 1980.  But our real claim is that our actual 1956 DeSoto is in the movie, driven by my brother-in-law.  And my Sister-in-law was at the dance.  They were both in high school and got non-paying jobs as extras, just for fun.  My husband and I drove the 1956 De Soto the first year we were married, then gave it to his brother because it was too old to drive cross-country when we moved to Boston.

Lovely reflections on those special dogs who connect with you so deeply. It moved me to think of our latest doggie. We have a little Aussie right now who loves us so much we feel almost unworthy, and also a little guilty because the urge to herd is so deep I almost wish there was some kind of rent-a-sheep option for just such animals. I mean, sometimes we humans are not allowed to be in different rooms in the house. We're corralled and barked at and hustled together.  I admire his leadership abilities and his joy in life. It's love all right, but I don't know if this Aussie is The One.

@Sam Lyons

Thank you for sharing these memories. 

Of all the cats I've adopted or fostered over the years, THE ONE was a scruffy boy who seemed to have every physical ailment possible (heart, immune system, no teeth [husband nicknamed him Droolius Caesar]) but was the sweetest little soul. The first day we brought him home from the shelter, he slept on my chest all night. He was such a good boy. We only had him for three years before his little heart finally gave out (after many trips to the cardiologist... thank god for pet health insurance). He's our only cat buried in the backyard because I couldn't bear to watch the traveling veterinarian take him away after taking away his pain.

I'm not crying. You're crying. 😭

@john ezra

Two of my three “The One” dogs were herders, though not quite as, er, dogged as you describe your Aussie to be. Is he an Aussie shepherd or a kelpie? 

The Dog was an Aussie cattle dog—not to mention tree climber (after squirrels) and KUDZU avoider (even with squirrels in it) when we lived below the Mason-Dixon Line for a few years—but she never heel-nipped or corralled. I had found her on my way to work one day: She’d just walked into the morning traffic with a friend, a boxer, looking to escape our neighborhood for the Sangre de Cristo foothills on the other side of the road. I jackknifed my SUV across the two lanes and opened the rear hatch. The boxer ran for the hills; The Dog jumped into my arms, and from there into the back of my car. 

I thought she’d got lost. I ran an ad; I put up signs. Our vet told us, however, that she’d likely bombed as a cattle-herding ranch hand and was subsequently dumped in our “nice neighborhood.” She said that, sadly, the story was a common one in Santa Fe. 

Her having failed as a herding professional was a blessing. Good Freyya, those needle-sharp puppy teeth… Painful enough during tug of war; would have drawn real blood from sockless heels. 

I would have loved to see The Dog now in the Old World with us. My husband used to say that you could take a canine hick off a dusty ranch in NM, but you could. not. take the NM ranch, etc. The eager-eyed, oh so uncultured constam barking… Oh, the barking…

I feel your pain, John.

@Beth

I am so sorry for your heartbreak. Nature ought not to ever give us only three years with them. 

The Dog is buried in our backyard back home, too. I also couldn’t bear for the traveling vet to take her away. My husband said he’d only heard me make the sound I did that day once before: When another traveling veterinarian had come to another house of ours in another state, when our Rhody left us. By the way, any vet who makes doing this great, heartbreaking service for us a part of his practice is as kind a soul as ever walks the Earth.  

There’s now a nervous little dance my heart does each month when Señor Gato goes in for his arthritis shot. We don’t know how old our (also drooly and almost entirely toothless—and, by the way, thankgod for pet dental insurance) wonder kitty is. The vet back home had guessed “10 years, could be more” when El Señor picked us as his new humans. So now each month that his good health is reaffirmed is a gift. Our new vet here administers Solensia every 4 weeks without a peep of protest from the kitty, then he runs his large, capable hands over the little body with the slow touch of someone who knows animals in a way he doesn’t know—or care to know—people. I already trust this man as much as I’ve ever trusted any of our animals’ doctors. He says little; he makes even less eye contact with us. It’s clear, though, that what he does for a living is a calling, not a career. 

As for Señor Gato, well, a cat can definitely be The One dog, too.

@MBM There are often “gimmicks” like this on Sundays (and especially Thursdays). Sometimes the trick is to enter more than one letter in a square (we call that a rebus, and instructions are here: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/crosswords/rebus-crossword-puzzle.html ), sometimes it’s something else. Stick around a while and you’ll get the hang of it, and hopefully begin to look forward to the extra little aha you get from figuring it out! Welcome!

@MBM Many of experience pain upon our first rebus encounter... many grow to really enjoy discovering them. Others never do. I hope you are one of the former. In any case, here's an excellent article written by our own Deb Amlen all about rebus puzzles. Hopefully, you'll judge them more kindly after you read this. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/crosswords/rebus-crossword-puzzle.html?unlocked_article_code=1.Ek8.mXsj.965_QInPlFhk&smid=url-share

@Nancy J. Thank you for this. The first time I heard Tom Waits was sometime in 1976. I was living in Seattle, where a friend and I had moved after college because it was 2000 miles from the small coal mining town where we’d lived. I didn’t have a car…I didn’t need one, being in Seattle with its mass transit, and with my living two miles from the bank where I’d gotten a job, I often walked. I had no interest in banking, but was drawn to it because T S Eliot had been a banker and I thought I was a poet. 

One day, a senior VP needed some documents run to one of our branches and asked if I’d take them. When I said I didn’t have a car, he gave me the keys to his…I forget the make, but it was a small, silver sports car of some kind. It was a stick shift and while I’d learned on a car with a manual transmission, I’d not driven one in a few years…and I’d certainly never driven one in Seattle, with its hills. At every stop light I was struck with near panic that I’d get my timing with the clutch wrong, stall out and roll back into the car behind me, wrecking my boss’s boss’s very expensive car.

It wasn’t the smoothest drive but I did get to the branch without incident, and as I pulled into the parking spot at the curb, Tom Waits’ “Step Right Up” came on the radio. I’d never heard anything like it, so I sat there, transfixed until it was over. The next time I was in a record store, I bought the album, then another, and I’ve been a fan since.

So, thank you for sharing this.

Not long after I moved to Kenosha In 1996, I learned that pilots that owned "warbirds" (military trainers and combat aircraft) would fly to the local airport a few days before the Experimental Aircraft Association (EAA) Fly-In up in Oshkosh. They did that because Kenosha County allowed formation flying, and the pilots didn't often get a chance to do it.

One of the other activities back then was a "bombing run", where a navigator would throw a package of flour out of the plane at a target on the ground (at a small ultralight airfield). I got to see this contest only once, as I had to work the other years they had the contest. The target that year was…

A BLOW-UP DOLL

The closest anybody got to it was about six feet. The most impressive thing I remember was seeing war planes flying toward me at less than 100 feet off the ground and being glad that the only ammo was a sack of flour.
